docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It was with great interest that I read the article about egg donors being sought by a Connecticut in vitro fertilization program (''Connecticut Company Seeks Egg Donors,'' June 17). The article implies that there is a lack of I.V.F. and donor egg services in Westchester County. We at the Montefiore Fertility and Hormone Center in Dobbs Ferry have provided I.V.F. and donor egg services for 15 years. The use of donor eggs has proven successful for women with infertility related to aging or premature menopause. As a licensed New York State Reproductive Tissue Bank, we have participated in the screening of many egg donors. At our center, most egg donors find the experience rewarding with the knowledge that they are assisting an infertile couple in their quest to have a child. BARRY WITT, M.D. Medical director The Fertility and Hormone Center Montefiore Medical Center

headline.main: In Vitro Fertilization Services Available in County

docs.abstract: Montefiore Medical Center Fertility and Hormone Center medical director Barry Witt letter on June 17 article notes center has provided in-vitro fertilization for 15 years

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Health Infrastructure for AIDS'' (editorial, July 2) says that ''except in the remotest communities, most African women give birth in medical facilities.'' Yet according to the World Health Organization, only 8 percent of Ethiopian women, 18 percent of Sudanese women and 31 percent of Nigerian women do so. One in 11 women in East Africa risks maternal death during her lifetime, compared with 1 in 4,000 women in Western Europe.
docs.abstract: Cynthia Steele letter gives statistics contradicting July 2 editorial assertion that most African women, outside remotest communities, give birth in medical facilities (S)
